title: Indignation and action through anger
content: As opposed to guilt, anger may actually be a powerful initiator for action, as it doesn’t paralyse but rather activates. Anger is an emotional reaction that searches to resolve fear through confrontation, in order to stop an outside threat. (Wikipedia contributors, 2020h) Induced by fear, anger is capable of becoming a mobilising spark for positive action, for example liberation movements stimulated by collective outrage. Various contemporary and historical examples like union strikes or liberation struggles show the positive potential of collective disruptive action to affect change. On the other hand, it may as well become a destructive and painful outlet of uncontrolled anger and violence: “Fear leads to anger. Anger leads to hate. Hate leads to suffering.” (Lucas, 1999) Outrage may as well result in vicious and violent movements like for example the November Pogroms 1938. (Wikipedia contributors, 2020f)
